pullRequest.body:
Defined Ordinal.IsClosed and Ordinal.IsAcc and proved basic lemmas about them. This is closedness in the club-sense.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

This was discussed before on #14060. `Ordinal.IsClosed` is equivalent to an appropriate topological property, and the proof will be in a later pr.

`IsClosed.sInter` and `IsClosed.iInter` can also be proven topologically once the equivalence is proven, but since they are needed for proofs unrelated to the topological equivalence I want to have them here without needing the whole topology proof.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [3f49ab3351](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16710/commits/3f49ab3351fdd84d6d15edbad7bdad1e496733c4)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsAcc`
`+ IsAcc.forall_lt`
`+ IsAcc.inter_Ioo_nonempty`
`+ IsAcc.isLimit`
`+ IsAcc.mono`
`+ IsAcc.pos`
`+ IsClosedBelow`
`+ IsClosedBelow.forall_lt`
`+ IsClosedBelow.iInter`
`+ IsClosedBelow.sInter`
`+ _`
`+ accPt_subtype`
`+ clusterPt_principal`
`+ isAcc_iff`
`+ isClosedBelow_iff`
`+ isLimit_of_not_succ_of_ne_zero`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

I had a quick look through the discussion in #14060, but the conclusion there seems to be that we should define these things topologically anyway? That is, it seems more sensible to re-use IsClosed from the order topology on ordinals, and have a lemma saying it's closed in the topology sense iff `∀ p < o, (o ≠ 0 ∧ ∀ p < o, (S ∩ Ioo p o).Nonempty) → p ∈ S`.
I guess the idea is that that lemma will be pretty awkward to work with, and IsAcc is useful to have anyway... So I'm happy to have IsAcc, but I'm not convinced about Ordinal.IsClosed. What do you think @vihdzp? In any case, let's definitely add the TODO to show this is equivalent to the topology thing.

The issue is that we want to talk about sets of ordinals being closed "below an ordinal". That is, we have a set `s : Set Ordinal` and we talk about it being closed below `o`, rather than having a set `s : Set (Iio o)` be closed. So the conversion between these definitions and the topological ones isn't quite so clean as it might seem. The topological equivalences are still useful to have, but I do think it's alright having two different predicates like this.

> I had a quick look through the discussion in #14060, but the conclusion there seems to be that we should define these things topologically anyway? That is, it seems more sensible to re-use IsClosed from the order topology on ordinals, and have a lemma saying it's closed in the topology sense iff `∀ p < o, (o ≠ 0 ∧ ∀ p < o, (S ∩ Ioo p o).Nonempty) → p ∈ S`. I guess the idea is that that lemma will be pretty awkward to work with, and IsAcc is useful to have anyway... So I'm happy to have IsAcc, but I'm not convinced about Ordinal.IsClosed. What do you think @vihdzp? In any case, let's definitely add the TODO to show this is equivalent to the topology thing.

Like vi said, the topological equivalent isn't as simple as we hoped because it talks about the topology of `Iio o`, not `Ordinal`. It's `IsClosed {x : Iio o | x.1 ∈ A}`. We shouldn't write this kind of thing all the time so that's why I think it warrants a definition. I already have the topological equivalences for both somewhere and I'll PR them when this gets merged, but I'll add a TODO anyways in the meantime.

My two cents:
* I would also prefer to define this in terms of topological notions. In a completely different project, I've realized it is useful to have the notions `A is open in B` or `A is closed in B` in a topological space, and ideally `Ordinal.IsClosed S o` should just become `IsClosedIn S (Iio o)`, and something similar for accumulation points.
* I am happy to quickly merge API about `IsClosedIn`/`IsOpenIn` for topological spaces (maybe after a brief message on Zulip if there are any objections to this idea). 
* We could merge this in the meantime, with the idea (and an explicit comment) that this should be refactored later. If we do that, the name `IsClosed` should probably be `IsClosedBelow` or something.
I like this `IsOpenIn` idea. I'm not really sure how its API should look though, do we just translate the basic results on open/closed sets to this setting and leave it at that?

We can start small: just have all the lemmas how `IsOpenIn`/`IsClosedIn` interacts with intersections, unions, `univ` and `IsOpen`/`IsClosed` (e.g. if `B` is closed then `IsClosedIn A B \iff IsClosed (A \inter B)`). We can increase the API as we use it more.
If you want to write the basic API for this, that would be great!
You can use https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Notation.html#Set.Notation.%C2%ABterm_%E2%86%93%E2%88%A9_%C2%BB to define `IsOpenIn`/`IsClosedIn`.
I've opened that PR in #17854. For now I've only added relative open/closed sets; if there's no objections I'll add `AccPtIn` as well in a follow-up.

> My two cents:
> 
> * I would also prefer to define this in terms of topological notions. In a completely different project, I've realized it is useful to have the notions `A is open in B` or `A is closed in B` in a topological space, and ideally `Ordinal.IsClosed S o` should just become `IsClosedIn S (Iio o)`, and something similar for accumulation points.
> * I am happy to quickly merge API about `IsClosedIn`/`IsOpenIn` for topological spaces (maybe after a brief message on Zulip if there are any objections to this idea).
> * We could merge this in the meantime, with the idea (and an explicit comment) that this should be refactored later. If we do that, the name `IsClosed` should probably be `IsClosedBelow` or something.

I'm renaming and adding the TODO. Did you end up opening a zulip discussion about this?
Yes, and now it seems that it's contentious whether we even want relative open/closed sets given the `∩↓` is available. At this point I'd rather just see this PR merged rather than keep stalling.

I disagree. I think this PR has to change to `IsOpenIn s t` or `IsOpen (s ↓∩ t)`, and only the former is currently stuck by Zulip. I'm happy to merge it if you adapt the code to use the latter option.

About the accumulation point, is that the same as [AccPt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Defs/Filter.html#AccPt) (without relativization), since an ordinal cannot be approached from above? If so, please also use that

Ah, I see in the Zulip thread that `IsClosedBelow` is `IsClosed ((S ∩ Iio o) ∪ {o})`, so it's not even a special case of `IsClosedIn`? My bad then, then that API wouldn't help here.

Could you add the equivalence between `IsClosedBelow` and `IsClosed` of that complicated set? Or if that's hard, we can merge it as-is.

> Ah, I see in the Zulip thread that `IsClosedBelow` is `IsClosed ((S ∩ Iio o) ∪ {o})`, so it's not even a special case of `IsClosedIn`? My bad then, then that API wouldn't help here.
> 
> Could you add the equivalence between `IsClosedBelow` and `IsClosed` of that complicated set? Or if that's hard, we can merge it as-is.

It is a special case. `IsClosedBelow` is equivalent to `IsClosed (Iio o ↓∩ S)`, `((S ∩ Iio o) ∪ {o})` is just adding all the possible acc points of `S ∩ Iio o` to it (only 1) so that asking if it's closed is the same as asking if it's closed inside `Iio o`.

I'm currently changing the definition to `IsClosed (Iio o ↓∩ S)` and adding a theorem characterizing it with the current def, I think that's what people want? tbh I still think it's silly not using the original definitions and having the topological ones as theorems (to me it's like defining limit ordinals as accumulation points of `Ord`, which is obviously not done), but this was argued over a lot so now I'm just going along with whatever gets this merged.

I understand your point that it might be a bit silly to give a characterization w.r.t. the topology instead of a direct order-theoretic one, but I think it's important for Mathlib to unify definitions (either use the same definition in many places, or at least show the relations between them). This reminds me of the case of suprema on ordinals: before they were their own definitions, and now (I believe) they have been unified with the standard notion of suprema on conditionally complete lattices, which is nicer.

> to me it's like defining limit ordinals as accumulation points of `Ord`, which is obviously not done

Note that as part of my planned ordinal refactors (#17033), `IsLimit` will get replaced with the more general [`IsSuccLimit`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/SuccPred/Limit.html#Order.IsSuccLimit). Part of what makes the current definition annoying is that the API for it had to be duplicated for ordinals and cardinals. Redefining `IsLimit` as an accumulation point would have been another way to solve that problem :P

Things are working with the new definition, although the proof of `accPt_subtype`, which is the bulk of the equivalence between the old and new definition, is quite the ugly proof. There is probably a neater way to prove it but I'm not seeing it. I'm also unsure about its name and some other names of the new theorems.
Just reasserting my LGTM. I'm excited to see club sets in the near future!
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11525022791/job/32086422014)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11525022791/job/32086421713)

This looks good to me now, up to some minor things.

I agree that `clusterPt_principal` is nicer as an `iff`.
Only a few minor remarks.

This looks good to me now, up to some minor things.

I agree that `clusterPt_principal` is nicer as an `iff`.
You don't need to change anything, but fyi `IsLimit` will probably be defined in terms of `IsSucc(Pre)limit` soon and this theorem will be deprecated.
I may have asked this in the previous PR but, you do need the condition `o ≠ 0` for this match the topological notion, right? Getting rid of degenerate cases should only be done for good reasons.

I added it originally so that `0` won't have to be in every club. It could also be a requirement in `IsClosed` instead, but yea then `IsAcc` won't match the topological notion. This felt like the more natural place to put it.
Alright, glad to see this is a cut and dry case.
Not on my laptop rn, but can you golf this by doing it backwards? That is, do `apply Isclosed.sInter` and finish by `mem_range` in the next or even the same line.

Does this work?
```suggestion
    {p : Ordinal} (hp : p < o) : (U ∩ Ioo p o).Nonempty := hU.2 p hp
```
Can you uniformize the variable names by using `S` here instead?
Also here.
Note that `h` is equivalent to `x ∈ closure C` by `mem_closure_iff_clusterPt`. Also, isn't this an iff?
I can make it into an iff but will the other direction ever be used? We have both `Or` cases as theorems already.
Well, the other thing nice about iffs is that you can use them in `rw`. That seems at least somewhat plausible.

I think this should work
```suggestion
alias ⟨IsClosedBelow.forall_lt, _⟩ := isClosedBelow_iff
```
It does but then you need an extra parentheses around `.forall_lt`, ie `(h C CmemS).forall_lt p plto ...` -> `((h C CmemS).forall_lt) p plto ...`
That doesn't seem right, function application doesn't need parentheses.

Alright, I think i figured it out. Creating the alias automatically turned some arguments from implicit to explicit, arguments like `S` that are part of the definition of `IsClosedBelow`. So then `(h C CmemS).forall_lt p` didn't typecheck because `(h C CmemS).forall_lt` expected the now explicit arguments `S` and `o`. But apparantly surrounding an expressing like that with parentheses forces lean to fill in these inputs, so `((h C CmemS).forall_lt) = (h C CmemS).forall_lt C o`.

Also I'm now seeing that this problem just went away hahaha. I must have copied something wrong and somehow made the alias have explicit inputs or something.

Iffs generally have their arguments implicit.
```suggestion
theorem isClosedBelow_iff {S : Set Ordinal} {o : Ordinal} : IsClosedBelow S o ↔
```

```suggestion
theorem IsAcc.mono {o : Ordinal} {S T : Set Ordinal} (h : S ⊆ T) (ho : o.IsAcc S) :
```
I think `mono` is a much more common name in Mathlib.

I don't think this should hold up this PR since this is an issue with a lot of the other theorems in the file but, this should hold for any linear `SuccOrder`, right? If so it'd be nice to add a TODO.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(SetTheory/Ordinal/Topology): define Ordinal.IsClosed and Ordinal.IsAcc
